DOC.HEAD: Government to Unveil Sweeping Reform Program
Eds: ADDS 3 grafs on Yugoslav paper publishing greetings from exiled prince
With AM-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Communist premier has warned that his government will resign if Parliament rejects a package of austerity measures he plans to submit Monday to contain hyperinflation. The three-day parliamentary session has already been billed in the media as ``D-day'' for Yugoslavia, with a sharp clash expected between liberals and conservatives representing the country's different regions. Premier Ante Markovic's government, which took over in March, has moved fast to introduce market mechanisms as a way out of Yugoslavia's worst-ever economic crisis, marked by a 2,000 percent annual inflation rate, a $17 billion foreign debt and a 17 percent unemployment rate. His reform program has been criticized by conservatives in Yugoslavia's Communist leadership, especially in the republic of Serbia, who oppose his market-oriented efforts and the promotion of greater political pluralism. Several key government-sponsored reforms have been blocked by the conservatives, and Markovic is expected to demand urgent changes in Yugoslavia's constitution that would give more power to the federal government to implement its program. The new austerity package has been kept under strict secrecy, and speculation about the measures have caused a huge shopping spree by Yugoslavs fearing their effect. ``Never before in (postwar) parliaments have there been so many expectations and so much guesswork,'' about a session of Parliament, the state-run Tanjug news agency said Sunday. Last week, the U.S. State Department said it was worried by rising tensions in Yugoslavia and urged the people to unite in support of Markovic's reform program. The tough reform measures are expected to include a substantial devaluation of the national currency, the dinar, and tight monetary and budgetary controls accompanied by stiff wage and price discipline. But government spokesmen have denied rumors of a wage and price freeze. The government has already announced that if the package is passed, the country would receive ``substantial financial aid,'' including a loan of up to $1 billion from the International Monetary Fund and some Western countries. In Serbia, the largest of the country's six member republics, the opposition to Markovic's reforms is centered on claims that he has done nothing to curb rampant inflation. Fearing popular discontent that could be sparked by the austerity program and the economic reforms, Serbian authorities have instead proposed short-term measures designed to bring down inflation. In an apparent attempt to pressure the government, the state-run trade unions of Serbia and its ally Montenegro have announced short general warning strikes for next week to coincide with the parliamentary session. Some delegates at the current Serbian Communist Party congress have demanded that the Serbian parliamentary deputies not even vote on Markovic's package, saying they should demand his immediate resignation. Markovic has repeatedly stressed that if his program is not approved in Parliament he will tender the Cabinet's resignation. A prolonged dispute between the leaderships of Yugoslavia's constituent states over the country's political and economic future came to a head in November, when Serbia broke off all business and government ties with the northern region of Slovenia. Janez Drnovsek, head of Yugoslavia's collective state presidency, was expected to address the parliamentary session with a report on the deep splits that have developed between the constituent regions and on measures to curb the crisis. In another development, a Christmas message from Crown Prince Alexander, now a London resident, was published in the Sunday edition of the Vjesnik daily newspaper in Zagreb. It was the first time such a thing has been done in the country's 44-year Communist history. Alexander's father, the late Peter II, was Yugoslavia's last king. The monarchy was abolished when the Communists came to power after World War II and male members of the exiled royal family were banned from returning.
